Fields.DialogueText: *ALARM*
@BATTLE
Merde.
Is this a--
*CRACK*
It is never a bad time, Capitaine. You are my superior.
That too.
... Oui. Tire!
*CRACK*
Writer's block?
Of a sort.
Yeah, that last Morgana storm was really something. Sometimes I feel like I'm still there.
I do not. I am not. Tire!
*CRACK*
Right. You process this stuff a lot quicker.
Where do babies come from, Capitaine?
... Don't take this the wrong way, Verdun, but what the hell?
Bon. I was in that same frame of mind when Elise posed the question in her latest letter. I would hear your perspective.
Right. Of course.
My expertise is with men deafened by artillery and blinded by gas, shivering in earth made cold till trench turns to grave. How must I answer a seven-year-old girl about... this?

Fields.MenuText: Can't you just deflect?

Fields.DialogueText: If I do not give her an answer, a liar might.

Fields.MenuText: Something about the cruisers and the carriers?

Fields.DialogueText: I am not trying to warp her, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Anything but the truth.

Fields.DialogueText: She has seen war, after all. She can wait a bit for love.
I'm a little surprised that you're asking me.
Who else would I ask but a confidant?
That's one word for it.
I suppose if I keep waiting for the right one, I shall never get anything down. Fleury, avec moi.
Meow.
*HISS*
Verdun, the cat's going off.
Don't spoil her, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
Oui.
Extra fish for her, then?
I deflected, Capitaine.
I saw. You just kind of slapped that Morgana shell aside.
Non. Elise.

Fields.MenuText: Good. It's not your responsibility.
How'd you do that?
Why would she have asked in the first place?

Fields.DialogueText: If I keep this up any longer it might become my responsibility.
I regaled her with stories from the front. Censored, of course.
She's curious about the world. Children are part of the world.
I have headed this off, but this is threatening to get out of hand.
Don't take it so seriously. She's just a curious kid.
War is not a curiosity. She is scarcely old enough to entertain the idea.
Then why entertain her?
I have learned that children can be... perceptive. She can be, at least. If she asks a question, it is usually because she has given some thought to an answer.
Perhaps she will realize that a Guépard-class destroyer is no fit pen pal for a small human.
Perhaps not. She's lasted this long.
She says boys are icky. There is hope for her yet.
Well, it's about to get ickier around here. We're taking on some new crew when next we make port.
Dieu merci. The decks were starting to lose their shine.
Don't hurt them. You know that by now.
No more than is necessary. You know that by now. Shall we skip the flirting and get to the night's business?
I'll put the kettle on. Scones?
Lingonberry.
Those are the new recruits, then?
Some of them. They're awaiting your review.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
And the rest?
Starting now. To your stations. And you - brush up on your French.
Above. They'd requested watch detail as soon as was practicable.
Comme c'est consciencieux. You know, some of the other navies allow their Belles a firmer hand in crew selection.
Allow me to be the judge of that.

Fields.MenuText: They know what they're doing.

Fields.DialogueText: I can see in one's eyes the depths of their courage and resilience. If I am to see something shallow staring back, I would prefer it be before we've left port.

Fields.MenuText: Some of the other navies screen for blood purity. What's your point?
You've got a good eye for good people.

Fields.DialogueText: Their malfunction. But at least they can screen for anything at all.
They've been through training already. That won't be necessary.
Bon. They have chosen an unfortunate place to be thrown overboard.
They most certainly have not.
Ah, so they can swim.
That's not what I--
One more thing, Capitaine.
Verdun?
You know I find you compelling. Intriguing. Perhaps even comforting. This is not for the sailors to know.
I wasn't going to carry you over the threshold into the mess hall.
We Belles are all that stand between you and a thousand seaborne hells. Our weaknesses are mechanical. Tactical. Not emotional. Do I make myself clear?
I... sure. Yes.
Cela doit suffire.
Marin! Identify yourself!
Ma'am! Private First Class Hickman!
American. As I suspected. Well, that can be cured.
Who was that one we just took on last tour...
We picked up that new turret captain in Calais, didn't we?
A fine addition. I don't think we've dropped a shell on his watch yet. Almost perfect.
Almost?
He snores awfully, Capitaine. I can hear it no matter where I am. Feel it, even.
There's Verdun's cat now. What's she got there?
A... dead butterfly. Thanks, I think?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
*PURR*
You too? I have never understood this tendency of hers.
It's a cat thing. They like bringing their kills to share with their family. I think it's cute.
I wonder if Command would feel the same way were we to tow a Morgana into port.
... Verdun, it's a butterfly.
Fleury's to do with as she pleases. She is a cat. She will think of something.
Hmm... you know, I think I'll keep it.
Whatever for?
I've got pins in my quarters. Might be nice to spruce up the map.
Dead insects as decoration?
Well, look at it this way. Those flowers on your hat - what are they about?
Bleuets de France. I wear them in memory of those touched by the Great War - soldiers, civilians, widows, orphans - now that we have earned the right to grieve.
It reminds you of what you fought for.
Every day.
We must have picked up this butterfly when we were in port. It's a nice reminder of the land we're protecting.
You could not possibly compare the two.
Now, how best to preserve this... ?

Fields.MenuText: I'm not. But it's a memento nonetheless.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I like it.
Have you ever seen a butterfly?

Fields.DialogueText: I do not wear these bleuets because I like them.
I have seen this one. I am not impressed.
Humidity. Combined with an antiseptic to keep mold off.
What?
The butterfly needs to be relaxed enough to be posed.
How do you know this?
There should be some surgical spirits that will keep it sterile.
Why do you know this?
Rudimentary medical knowledge. Anyone could do this.
I appreciate it, Verdun. Thank you.
I do not have to understand why this pleases you. But it does. And... this pleases me.
That doesn't.
Non, it does. Just... differently.
Almost... almost...
Gah! Where was the alarm?
Fleury's disappeared somewhere. She'll be found when she wants to be. Aux armes!
@BATTLE
Capitaine, they are right on top of us!
Who was on watch?
One of the new lookouts. He'll be disciplined accordingly.
I know that tone. You mean to keep me from having a part in it.

Fields.MenuText: You can be a little overzealous with the crew.
It's not about you.
I'm sure I'd make my point all the better if you just glared at him.

Fields.DialogueText: Hundreds may die for the negligence of one. There is no such thing.
When I may be sunk at any moment by wily Morganas? I rather think it is.
He should be so fortunate.
Tell me truly. Was it the American?
Who? Hickman? No, it was--
My judgment remains intact. Bon.
I will be personally shadowing the recruits, Capitaine.
For how long?
Until I look in the eyes of each one and see naught but clarity of purpose.
Verdun.
I shall harbor no sick hearts that honor could not move.
Verdun.
Capitaine?
You're alive. I'm alive. We're all still in this fight.
Capitaine, I--
How are you?
... Fine. Did you get it displayed?
Right where we found it. One butterfly, pinned right there in--
The Celtic Sea. Mon Dieu.
What is it?
... Nothing. By your leave, Capitaine.
So close...
A security leak?
That's a serious accusation, Verdun, especially when we don't even know who we're accusing.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
I don't know why I didn't see it before. The problem with our new recruits is not incompetence. It is malice.
Which is why I am prosecuting this accusation as seriously as possible.
That stuff you said about shadowing the recruits?
One at a time until I find what I am looking for.
Until this mystery is solved, we ought to consider this ship on high alert. If we've been surprised once, we can be surprised again.
If I jump at shadows, it is because something has cast them.

Fields.MenuText: We barely even know what that is.
Well, it's you. They know what they signed up for.
You can get to the bottom of it.

Fields.DialogueText: I will deal with this problem as efficiently as I deal with the Morganas.
With permission. Unless in the event of an emergency.
We still haven't determined that this isn't just a fluke.
If it is not, then the crew's senses will be honed to a killing edge.
If anyone can find out what's going on, it's you. Just stay skeptical. People tend to find what they are looking for.
If they are properly looking, yes.
Verdun, that's not what I--
Your list of suspects just got shorter.
Unless they are laying low. Meet me on the bridge.
Looks like I'm going to have to disguise those packages a little better...
Any luck?
Just making conversation.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
You ask after answers quite early.
And I am making an observation. Your instinct is commendable.
Oh. Well, thank you, Ver--
Yet unnecessary. I have this matter firmly under control.
Not yet. But if I am thorough, luck will be inevitable.

Fields.MenuText: So... any luck?
Are you complimenting me or not?
Along with a few other matters. Is that a work order for new guns?

Fields.DialogueText: If I were displeased, you would know.
The recruits I have shadowed go about their duties diligently and without resentment.
While you're watching.
You cannot fake devotion, Capitaine. A twitch of the eye... the set of one's jaw... The body strives to express what the soul has determined to hide.
I hope you're writing that down somewhere.
Perhaps once we have solved our security leak. How is the mail?
Airtight. Nothing steamed open, nothing ticking.
I am glad you volunteered to keep watch on that front. It is not in me to complain...
But?
I have occasionally seen the crew at their letters. In the mess hall, and elsewhere. You know I can read a page at a glance.
Too sad?
I have seen meadows vascularized with trenches choked by the mad and the dying.
Right. Dumb question.
Non. That same memory, that same recall... it stirs the imagination to brighter things, if something appears to stir it. Home. Family. A stroll through a field untouched by...
... My mind wanders. I prefer to keep it from wandering. You help in this. Merci.
Nothing wrong with brighter things.
Brighter. Not better.
Oh! Speaking of, you've got a letter. A certain little girl's handwriting is getting better.
It will have to wait.
Have a look, Capitaine. I've taken some liberties.
I'm afraid to--
I know my specifications, I know the capabilities of the crew, and I know you'll agree with me when you see them put to use.
Hmm. German, predates the great war... but it hits hard.
There is yet a place for the classics.
Distract me.
Pardon?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Elise. The letters. Fleury. Sewing.
Those are your distractions. Well, that's not the right word, but--
I stopped a sailor at her swabbing and searched her face for lies. All I could think about was that the evening dress I'm making would complement her hair perfectly.
So where do I come in?

Fields.MenuText: Was she loyal?

Fields.DialogueText: She seemed quite relieved to get back to her work.

Fields.MenuText: That purple number with the red shawl?
I doubt that's all you could think about.

Fields.DialogueText: There's something about that shade of black that... Capitaine, stop it.
It was enough.
You have helped me to see the smaller, less pressing things in life. Help me not to. Give me an order. I cannot mix work and play.
Hate to break it to you, but that's kind of part of being--
I am not human.
All right, fine. But the mind wanders. Thoughts intrude. If anyone can deal with that, it's you. You don't dwell on things.
And if those things dwell in me?
Let them. They never really go away.
There was a time when we were staring down a Morgana - I think it was Dismay that day - and suddenly it occurred to me that I'd made a pot of tea and left it steeping.
And yet here we stand.
Here we stand.
... What kind of tea was it?
Some white tea. Chinese. Hard to find.
That narrows it down.
If... if you would allow it, I might--
Merde!
Damn. I'll have to fill these out later... while she's distracted.
Bon. That is another sailor down. Although...
There's a real lock in that one's step.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Ordinarily I would approve.
You're never ordinary.
I make the effort not to be. He, on the other hand...
Trying too hard?
He picked up speed at his task when he noticed me coming. That is not unusual... but his eyes held none of the guilt of one caught slacking.
Looked fine to me.
That is why you have me around. Look at my eyes, Capitaine. What do you see?
Patriotism, Capitaine. Honor. Even spite. Everyone worth a spot in a trench has something that drives them. I pride myself on my ability to see it.
So is the ocean. See that you don't drown in them.

Fields.MenuText: The color of a clear ocean on a sunny day. They're pretty.
Resolution. Determination. Fire.
My reflection.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps I'm not going soft after all.
Clearly I asked the wrong question.
This one was the first in whom I could not.
As long as he does his job, I don't think it should concern us.
Perhaps not. But you know my attention to detail, Capitaine. Sometimes periscopes lurk where the sun glistens upon the waves.
I'm glad I have you to look for them.
My duty, nothing more.
... Hmm. Verdun.
Capitaine.
What do you see in my eyes?
You don't have to answer that.
My reflection.
Private Hickman!
That may be the first time I've seen you hold a conversation with a sailor.
*HISS*
@BATTLE
Ma'am!
Where did you say you were from?
Ma'am! I--
At ease.
Winona. Minnesota.
Inland.
They couldn't keep me off the river.
Indeed. As you were.
Yes, Ma'am!
Outside of training, apropos of no matters of discipline or morale... yes.
I assessed his character and proved correct. But I always do that.
Impossible.

Fields.MenuText: Don't let them get used to it.
What changed?

Fields.DialogueText: Curiosity. But I could not describe it.

Fields.MenuText: That's nice to see.

Fields.DialogueText: I am still puzzling over it, but I appreciate your support.
Don't think about it too hard. You'll assess it away.
My nature, Capitaine, as with Fleury and her claws. Scratch and they will be eventually be new.
Where has she been, anyway?
Around. I have left fish out and it seems to be disappearing.
You can't sense her?
Believe me, Capitaine, I have tried.
Are cats immune to you?
She defeated my trap when first we met. Now she defeats my senses. Perhaps she is the spy we seek.
Well, she'll turn up. Keep me posted on your rivalry. That could actually go either way.
We have a common rival in you, Capitaine. Prepare yourself.
Wait... I hear her. And that can only mean--
Aux armes!
I told you she'd turn up eventually. Now she won't leave your side.
Wait, where's she going?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Or my feet. She seems determined to trip me.
I've never once seen you trip.
Nor shall you.
Capitaine, plus vite!
We're alive. That's what matters.
Fleury's senses grow sharper each day.
Like her claws. Ow...
Ignore her. What is... oh, mon Dieu.
What?
Un moment, Capitaine.
What's she after?
Capitaine, news from the infirmary. It's Hickman.
Is he...
Dead.

Fields.MenuText: Verdun, I'm so sorry.
What happened?
This was his first tour...

Fields.DialogueText: You did not kill him.
Shot by the witch herself.
The life expectancy on the Western Front was not much longer.
If you need to talk about any--
Capitaine, get down!
*THUD*
Gah! Verdun, let me--
False alarm! Everyone as you were!
Capitaine. Touch me again before the eyes of the crew and you will captain a ship with a benevolent poltergeist. Nothing more. Do I make myself clear?
Crystal. Ow...
Stand. You will walk it off.
Verdun, I--
Eh? Oh, um... sure.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Ah, Capitaine, you've arrived. Help me pin this.
Merci.
De rien.
Did I ever tell you about my first foray into leather?
One must use a heavier needle for material as thick as leather, but I had mislaid it. Powerful as I am, I could not quite get a grip to push the smaller needle I resorted to.
Clever. Do not flatter yourself.

Fields.MenuText: I, um... think I'd remember if you had.
I vaguely remember you requisitioning some.
I haven't seen it on any of your projects.

Fields.DialogueText: Hideously expensive. I traded a lot for it.
Stashed away. I am not yet satisfied with any of them.
So what did you do?
I used my teeth.
That makes my teeth hurt just thinking about it.
It worked. Once steeled for, a little discomfort is no great thing.
I'm glad you're keeping yourself occupied.
Machines may be maintained, Capitaine. Tactics may be refined. Examine the parameters of a battle, its belligerents... and the solution will become clear. I still believe this.
You didn't expect me to touch your arm.
I am much as I always am now. But human emotions are mutable. Unpredictable. In the moments after I discovered Hickman had been killed... so were mine.
You could have fooled me.
Because they are an old enemy of mine. Your intervention is the wild card. That, and how everyone perceives it. Sailor and Morgana alike, perched like a calm, disdainful crow.
That's kind of what I signed up for.
Perspective is a weapon known only to its wielder. My feelings were between us and us alone when I confessed them. I do not regret them.
But should there ever be an audience for our affection... especially once a battle is finished... it must be no more.
If that's how you feel.
Here is our first test. Be careful how you proceed, mon coeur.
How's the search going?
What would the cooks know?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Systematically. I started with the lookouts. Then the radio crew. Then the galley crew.
Perhaps that you would ask that very question.
Point.
Besides, they misplace things all the time. One of them was going on and on about how he can't let glass bottles out of his sight. It was odd enough to draw my attention.
I'm glad you're sifting through this... whether or not it's necessary.
Your duties as capitaine keep you from exercising the care you would like. One cannot very well repair a vehicle they are driving.
You should know that there is an unexpected side effect to my work.
Ambition has limits.

Fields.MenuText: Not with that attitude.
I'm glad the vehicle can do it herself.
It's good to take inventory now and again. Find anything interesting?

Fields.DialogueText: I shudder to imagine where we would be had I not awakened.
Even I was surprised. We've recovered some fascinating salvage from the most recent battle. Observe this manifest.
Oh?
I find myself on higher guard whenever Fleury is away.
You're starting to trust a cat over the crew?
She has not failed us once since we got her.
We?
You feed her too.
We ought to impose a moratorium on anyone else feeding her. She's not exactly slim these days.
... Non. It cannot possibly--
You will think me insane, Capitaine, but I may have found our exposed flank.
Wouldn't be the first time.
I'm just glad she let me have the mail...
You were busy that day.
Japanese?
Formerly. We will put it to a more noble use than the Morganas had in mind. Now, then...
... Where did we get a seaplane?
Verdun, were you hoping to find a traitor?
Random interrogations might create a few.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
If one exists.
Understand my reasoning, Capitaine. Give a person long enough in the bowels of chaos and the hellish will become mundane.
Unless you have a trench cat.
If anything stands out among the cacophony of shells and fire, it is a small animal. If someone is feeding her, I will know.
Look, I really don't think this is as big of a problem as you make it out to be. We've been on top of all possible threats since that one suprise attack.
She knows better now.

Fields.MenuText: Finally forgiven her for the dress she ate?
Using moments of calm against people. I'm not sure how to feel about that.
Can't let them get too used to a good thing.

Fields.DialogueText: You would prefer they use them against us?
They had their entire lives before the Morganas for that.
Our task is to keep the Celtic Sea free of Morgana contamination. I prescribe the fiercest vigilance.
Well, it's not all gloom and doom. That one sailor even seemed to be taking to it.
The soulless one?
I certainly wouldn't put it that way.
So you do know the one I mean.
Not one of my finer moments as captain, but yes.
I have often expressed frustration that you humans cannot be as committed as I to the war effort. But this one... is strange to me. I swear he stood to attention before my eyes even fell upon him.
Be careful what you wish for, eh?
I was thankful for an alarm system I could pet. I should have realized others could pet it as well.
Be on your guard. Anyone aboard could be hiding something.
All right, now where to hide these?
Thank goodness. It's a whole other war slipping anything by her.
Elise is not permitted here in port, of course. But she wanted to speak to me. The operator here will be able to connect us for a brief call.
I wish I'd grown up with a destroyer for a friend.
In among the mailbags. You said you had those under lock and key, aye?
And aboard her, no less. I thought these girls knew everything that went on.
For everyone's sake, you'll continue to think that.
Money talks.
Now to--
Capitaine.
Verdun! I didn't expect to see you here.
Nor should you. This is as far as I am able to manifest from my hull.
Did you meet the replacement for--
Hickman, yes. Ought to fit right in. He was nothing if not replaceable.
Well, that should conclude our business here in port.
As much of it as I cared to before the war's end.

Fields.MenuText: You've certainly done your mourning.
No shortage of recruits.
Did you happen to get a name, at least?

Fields.DialogueText: The war poetry practically writes itself.
I am not so cold as to lose track of my sailors.
Almost. I have a visitor here in Cork Harbour.
Who do you know in... ah.
If you had, you might not have taken one for a lover.
As little time as we have to act like it.
War is not kind to such desires. But I do appreciate the time we carve out.
Right. We'll find more.
Oui. À tout à l’heure.
Where was I? Right. Boxes.
Another one for the medical staff. American, if you don't mind terribly.
I welcome him. He will have plenty of work.
Right. Now it's just a matter of--
*ALARM*
Okay, first it's a matter of *that*.
@BATTLE
So what have we learned?
Largely nothing. Tire!
*CRACK*

Fields.MenuText: How's Elise doing?
Our traitor's still on the loose?
How's our new recruit?

Fields.DialogueText: She hates arithmetic.
Most likely.
Filling in commendably.
I didn't see you at breakfast today.
I was not hungry. Tire!
*CRACK*
You're frustrated.
I am thnking, Capitaine. My efforts so far have been...
Frustrated?
Always you test me. No wonder we are attracted to each other.
Forgive an uneducated guess. We're patrolling in the Celtic Sea.
Oui. Tire!
*CRACK*
One of whose ports is...
Cork.
Are we sure all this isn't just because you're putting a face to the statistics?
A seven-year-old face. I know where this leads, Capitaine.
Help me out here.
My conduct has been unbecoming of a destroyer of La Royale. I have bent my powers to an inefficient end.
You're not the first Belle to be a little paranoid. You were just trying to--
It would be more efficient for the crew to meet this end themselves.
... What? I mean, in what way?
It is so simple that I cannot believe I did not decide to do it first.
You never did favor the simpler things.
*ALARM*
For shame, Capitaine. Have you already forgotten how I captured our cat?
@BATTLE
"See something, say something?"
Positive externalities, I suppose.
They would sail into Hell aboard me. They ought to recognize demons when they see them. If anything suspicious goes on, our sailors will alert us. They know I am listening.

Fields.MenuText: You think they'll go for it?

Fields.DialogueText: You know our crew for dutiful and conscientious sorts. I have spent the entire tour making sure of this.

Fields.MenuText: So what if you just get a whole bunch of petty he-said, she-saids?
That'll just make everyone more secretive.

Fields.DialogueText: The Germans did. Even their leaders were surprised.
And you think I hold our crew in low regard.
When has anyone ever been able to hide anything from me?
I suppose there are more draconian measures out there.
Which I would be happy to employ, should the situation call for them.
Don't forget which of us is the captain.
You know this to be the simplest solution, Capitaine. Half the crew fear me. A small minority of the other half worship me.
I wonder if that other half is giving you ideas.
Jamais. I wish the Pope had never published that encyclical.
What was it called? "Calcare Aquam?"
"Treading Water," yes. Are we or are we not angels? That the question is even being asked is ludicrous.
Does it matter?
Faith alone answers that question for many, so it is bad enough to glance at it. It leads to unpleasant places. Still... the idea is useful enough for this purpose.
It's tempting, isn't it?
To be worshipped? To have every whim and instinct carried out by a devoted cohort of followers...
Well. Look around you. How has that worked out for your other gods?
I expect a fair bit gets lost in translation.
*ALARM*
Thank goodness I am here to clarify.
@BATTLE
All right, that's where it needs to be. Now I just wait until she--
Gah! I wish you wouldn't do that.
*BOOM*
@BATTLE
Capitaine.
I'll get to the bridge. For now, keep him away from Fleury.
Damn it! Again?
If I am such a nasty surprise, enemy fire must be downright paralyzing.

Fields.MenuText: I expect that on the battlefield.

Fields.DialogueText: You've got that look about you again. Something's up.
Love is a battlefield.

Fields.MenuText: Looks like you caught me. I'm doing a whole mess of smuggling.
You're pretty stunning yourself.

Fields.DialogueText: In a closet, no less. Bold.
You ought to see me from a Morgana's deck.
What look?
That "drop everything and attend to this or the war is lost" look. You know the one.
Perhaps I am too free with it. I thought I'd let you know how the initiative is going.
Find out anything?
Three stand accused of smoking on watch, another six of indecent language, and four of selling secrets to Morganas.

Fields.MenuText: They know what gets your attention.

Fields.DialogueText: I investigated them all. What is not nonsense is overreaction.
Can't imagine what that might look like.
Comme c'est mignon. It's the insubordination charges that interest me.
Insubordination? From whom?
The new recruit, for one. Hickman's replacement. We made conversation once or twice, and I can attest to his total subordination.
Then who accused him?
Why, Capitaine, I swore the crew to anonymity.
Of course you did.
Of course I did. It was the... quietly enthusiastic one.
That's a better way of putting it.
I've kept a record of all the denunciations. His all seem to apply to those I engage in casual conversation.
Someone was bound to notice. Still... why? Jealousy?
Merde. That's the last thing we need.

Fields.MenuText: Find out anything useful?

Fields.DialogueText: A smuggling ring - from which I seized some contraband in port. I suspect Surcouf's hand in this.
She won't be happy.
If we were able to find it, she will have had contingencies.
Huh. I thought she hated Italians.
She has no quarrel with their lira.
Right. And the crew complaints?
Indeed. I have the paperwork here.
An Italian gun? Where did this come from?
Explain, Capitaine.
Explain what?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
I took the liberty of searching the quarters of our denouncer-in-chief. Look at what I found.
Shell casings... strands of... Verdun, is this your hair?
Wait... this pin-up sketch... that's you?
Never mind his base obsessions. Look here.
A map... coordinates... Verdun, he's been recording our patrol route!
These coordinates are from the past week. His diary goes all the way back to that first surprise attack in these waters.

Fields.MenuText: It goes to... a fair few places.
Then why haven't we been drowning in Morganas?
He's been sending messages?

Fields.DialogueText: I know where this filth ought to go.
I'd beat the answer out of him, but he might enjoy it.
He was smart enough not to specify how, at least.
... You weren't searching the mail at all, were you?
What?
I left that salient to you to watch over. How else could you have let this slip?
Verdun, if I didn't catch it, the military censor would have. Who would he be writing to?
Who wouldn't he be writing to? We Belles are not the only ship spirits your kind have started worshipping! I specifically asked you--
"My kind." Is that the way you talk to Elise?
You dare bring her into--
This all started after that butterfly adventure. The Celtic Sea? Cork? Is your peace of mind worth the crew’s?
Or is a seven-year-old girl so critical to the war effort that you’d build disciplinary policy around her?
Why wouldn’t I, Capitaine? Do we Belles not grit our teeth against pain? Do we not armor ourselves against enemy fire? Do we not shield our weaknesses?
What happened to the bigger picture, Verdun? Or should I be flattered you’re spending our time and resources on turning the crew into good little machines?
You see? It's already working.
The mail's all yours.
Do what you like. I'm done with it.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
I look forward to double-checking.
An easy thing, to have done with nothing at all.
Check my closet, if you haven't already. I'm just renting the space.
Capitaine, perhaps this was a mistake.
What was? Spying on the crew? Having them denounce each other? I had to break up a fight on deck, you know.
A discipline problem I am certain I can resolve.
Is that your answer to everything? Discipline?
Offer the crew a hand in it and they will be united in our purpose.
The only way you could divide them more is if you brought back flogging.
We will cross that bridge when we come to it.
Well, you'll be happy to know that the source of our leak is on his way out. The little shrine to you he had going is grounds enough for a psychological discharge.

Fields.MenuText: How about we don't?

Fields.DialogueText: Never tie your hands.

Fields.MenuText: You're the one building the bridge.
It's a long, painful bridge, Verdun.

Fields.DialogueText: And you are the one burning it.
It will be a long, painful war.
Ah, York's Law.
What a weird incident that was. And she hadn't even awakened.
I am not particularly self-possessed. But one wonders what law they might name after me.
Or after an unfortunate sailor.
I will spend whatever and whoever I must for your safety.
My safety?
Our safety. Victory. And if one becomes inimical to the other, you know which I shall choose.
Focused as ever.
However much I must scratch away all else. However painful it may be. Aux armes, mon coeur.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
It's nice to get the drop on them for once.
We have our lookouts to thank. I will have to reward them.
What must that look like?
I've been meaning to get back into knitting.
You do that?
It gets cold out here.
Those look toasty.
I find myself in need of a project.
Easing off on the spy hunt?
We have our culprit. I admit I have been putting off the debriefing.

Fields.MenuText: He's just a human.
I can accompany you if you like.
I'll just be glad to be rid of him.

Fields.DialogueText: At last we understand each other. And yet... not.
I appreciate the sentiment, but I can handle him.
War is but one human madness. I can handle another.
Verdun... I wanted to apologize.
For?
The mailroom. At the time you were most concerned with people keeping secrets... I kept a whole mode of communication from you. And I threw it in your face when you called me on it.
You hid a gift from me in so doing. I appreciate the fabric you requisitioned. Was that what you picked up in port?
You knew?
Whatever of yours you kept hidden, Capitaine, I knew it could be no threat to me. Quite the opposite.
But I understand. If you can't trust me, who can you trust?
I love you, Capitaine, but I have never trusted you.
Not implicitly. I am not one to expose my flanks.
It is the nature of the enemy we face, and the nature of my response. Anything can be a weapon. Anyone can be a target. I must prepare to do whatever is necessary to face this.
The ship's been through a lot in the name of love. What happens when you hate something?
We win.
I suppose I should be happy you overlooked this.
What's this?
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Non, Capitaine. The Morganas are a welcome distraction.
Open it. Breathe it in.
... Verdun, where did you get this tea?
I traded half my velvet with one of the Japanese Belles for two pounds.
This is a year's supply!
Four, if you are careful with it.
I should be able to save some for later, too. The galley's bottles finally stopped disappearing.

Fields.MenuText: And to think if I'd done as you asked, the cat would have been out of the bag.

Fields.DialogueText: I am just glad Fleury didn't get into it.

Fields.MenuText: This ought to last us the rest of the war.
Do you have time for a pot?

Fields.DialogueText: One hopes.
Perhaps once we have secured the area.
... Oui. About that.
Hmm?
It is almost too simple for words. Catching my admirer solved both our problems.
How do you mean?
He wasn't using the mail, as it happens. You had nothing to look for.
... Are we seriously to believe that he was leaking our route to the Morganas via messages in bottles?
He confessed as much before we handed him over to the military police. It would explain the erratic nature of the surprise attacks.
I can't believe I didn't think of that.
Why would you, Capitaine? You are not given to obsession. Not like him. Not like... moi.
Do you need a moment?
Verdun, for the last time, you're not in trouble.
People tend to find what they are looking for.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
You were right, Capitaine. I bent our every effort toward this search. Whatever fruit it bore did not grow from the seed that planted it.

Hors sujet. If Command knew I was basing discipline and counterintelligence on the welfare of individuals of... dubious military value... they would have my head. I would have my head, in my right mind.
Look, I've got a lot on my plate right now. If you really want me to discipline you, it'll have to wait until tomorrow.
Bon. I will wait.
*THREE HOURS LATER*
Finally. Dinner?
I am not hungry.
I wouldn't expect so. You've been standing at attention all afternoon.
It is the least you are owed.
You're a more loving person than you give yourself credit for, Verdun. I'm not going to be scratched away that easily.

Fields.MenuText: How long were you planning on doing that?

Fields.DialogueText: As long as was necessary.

Fields.MenuText: And if the Morganas had attacked?
I'll be the judge of that.

Fields.DialogueText: I am repentant, Capitaine, not suicidal.
As you wish.
I suppose I can learn something else from Fleury.
What's that?
She has the uncanny ability to appear and disappear as she pleases. Yet somehow she always finds her way back into my lap.
Perhaps part of such an arrangement is trusting the other person to be out of your sight. Letting them learn and fight and... eventually come back.
And with practice, you can even step around them.
When necessary.
*HISS*
Who knows? They might learn to be a bang-up lookout.
As long as they are kept in fish.
Letter for you, Verdun. From Cork.
I asked her to imagine she had upset someone she cared strongly for. What might she do in such a circumstance, I wondered.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Technically, it is for us both. It concerns us both, that is.
It does not have to be.

Fields.MenuText: I thought romance wasn't Elise's forte.

Fields.DialogueText: Only in very specific hands with very specific intent.
Perhaps she may ghostwrite mine.

Fields.MenuText: Passing military secrets, are we?
This girl's going to write one hell of an autobiography.

Fields.DialogueText: If you ask a question, it's usually because you've given some thought to an answer.
Some. I deferred to her expertise.
A small human's expertise.
Experience is blind. We must seek it out wherever it may be.
Well, what did she say? Because I think I could use her advice as well.
She said she would explain herself and listen to the other person. Then she would do what she could to make it right.
See? You didn't need help.
Perhaps I did not. I was going to relax my shipboard regulations anyway.
But I am not alone in that decision. Allowing that to occur... allowing her to do this for me...
It's just a question, Verdun. Sometimes it's hard to answer even the obvious ones. That's what other people are for.
Well, while we are explaining ourselves...
Anything.
I must confess to a small dishonesty, Capitaine. I got you two presents.
What's the other one?
It is not regulation. We shall leave it at that for now.
Et... voila. You may open your eyes.
Verdun, what's... oh!
Frame your lips as though it were a kiss, Capitaine. I will respond in kind. I look forward to the day it is safe for them to meet.
You were right. That uniform's definitely not regulation.
I had just enough in gold and black to put a pattern together.
How long have you been working on this?
Since Fleury brought you that butterfly. A Queen of Spain fritillary, I believe.

Fields.MenuText: You'd know better than I would.

Fields.DialogueText: Call it reconnaissance.
Thank you, Verdun. I'm... honestly a little stumped now. On how to match this, I mean.

Fields.MenuText: I'm trying to think of an excuse to wear it.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps not until the war is won, but there it shall be.

Fields.MenuText: Fleury's got good taste.

Fields.DialogueText: In several ways.
Do not be. I am seamstress and soldier. I know my skills best. You know yours.
Tactics? Logistics?
Whatever name you wish to give it.
We may clash and drift apart, Capitaine. The arithmetic of the battlefield practically commands it. But when our enemies are driven from it, our purpose shall unite us.
Victory.
Memory. I believe we both pay closer attention to the flow of battle than we once thought. I will try harder not to question your determination.
There's no doubt about yours. You're no slouch at adaptation, either. Don't underestimate yourself.
*ALARM*
A tactical success for the Morganas.
An acceptable trade for a strategic victory.
We'll come back to this.
